not  on the same they are on different partitions
you'll need to reinstall your programs in either case, but your settings and data would be preserved if /home isn't reformatted
what do you see when you boot up?
that is a different, more serious problem
booting and starting X are two completely different things
reinstalls can be less painful under Linux, *IF* /home is its own partition
if /home is on the same partition as root, you'll probably want to try making a copy somehom with a liveCD

but if it's on the same partition as root, you'll need to back them up as they'll be wiped out.  You could run cfdisk or similar to create new partitions, and then copy your old /home into the partition you want for /home
what I've been doing is making a 12 GB (12.9 pseudogigabyte) partition at the flont of the drive for root, create a four GB partition at the end for swap, and make everything in between /home
what I describe is just one way to do it
it's the way that has worked best for me
just make sure that you back up what's on your /home that's part of root before you lose everything
good luck
